pr_title: Add `UnstableApi` annotation and hide some internal classes

timeline.message:
Add `UnstableApi` annotation and hide `DefaultRequestLog`

See: #2360

- Added the `UnstableApi` annotation to indicate unstable API.
- Annotated some classes and packages with the `UnstableApi` annotation.

Mark intermediary `StreamMessage` implementations as unstable

Also removed deprecated `onDemand()` calls.

timeline.bodyText: Does this effectively mean we only officially support our official client implementations, and user-created custom ones may potentially have breaking changes? I'm ok with either but we may want to document that explicitly (I lean towards not marking this unstable though it seems pretty well-baked).
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: I'm somewhat unsure about the stability of this API although it stayed unchanged for a very long time. For instance, a user may want to build a ClientFactory which is built on top of GrpcClientFactory or THttpClientFactory.
replies.author: trustin

timeline.bodyText: Just want to confirm, I think it's possible to hide some of these completely, is the idea to mark as unstable first and then hide later?
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: Is is possible to hide this class? Any user who wants to write a custom client implementation will need to use this API.
replies.author: trustin

replies.bodyText:
If I'm not mistaken, only the constructor is ever needed. So we should be able to hide it by providing a factory in *RequestContext.
This class is literally what prompted me to file the issue about over-exposed APIs ;)
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: I'm not sure if it's a good idea to have a static factory method with such large number of parameters. Perhaps it's better as it is now, i.e. public class annotated with @UnstableApi? It's for advanced users only anyway.
replies.author: trustin

replies.bodyText:
I think it's still worth it. Though if we can merge the semantics with our current builders maybe even better not sure it's possible.
These classes leak a lot of implementation details, including a whole class TimeoutController. I think they're so core that we want to hide them as much as possible.
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: Just realized that setTimeoutController and TimeoutController can be package-private. I think we can hide DefaultClientRequestContext if we do something about DefaultClientRequestContext.init(EndpointGroup). Not sure if it makes sense to move it to ClientRequestContext..
replies.author: trustin

replies.bodyText: Let me keep thinking about how we can solve this. Meanwhile, let me leave this as it is and address it in another PR. At least TimeoutController is now removed from public API.
